From the â€œkickedâ€ bob (an ultra-short crop with flicked out ends) to the â€œclaviâ€ cut (a mid-length chop that skims the clavicle or collarbone), we werenâ€™t short on haircut inspiration in 2024. But with a new year comes a fresh perspective â€” and countless more ways to wear our hair, too. If youâ€™re keen to switch things up this January, look no further. Ahead, we asked a handful of Londonâ€™s most sought-after hairstylists for their 2025 haircut predictions. Thereâ€™s something for everyone, whatever your hair type or texture. DashDividers_1_500x100 The Snack-Size Bob View this post on Instagram A post shared by Cassidy Gurev (@hairbycassidy_) Anita Rice, cofounder of Buller and Rice, says that the bob will live on in 2025 but itâ€™ll get even shorter. â€œThe snack-size bob, also known as the â€˜kickâ€™ bob, sits at the jawline and flicks out at the bottom,â€ Rice explains. â€œIt boasts blunt edges but thereâ€™s a lightly chopped texture [throughout] to add a little bit of versatility, so that you can flip around easily.â€ Rice suggests it works best with a side parting, slicked back with gel or mousse, or tucked behind the ears. The inspiration? Think musician LÃ¥psley, says Rice, or this cut posted to Instagram by hairstylist Cassidy Gurev of The Hair Bros.Â  The Boxie View this post on Instagram A post shared by Rubi (@poseandrepeat) The â€œbixieâ€, a cross between a bob and a pixie cut, is getting something of an upgrade for 2025. Enter: the â€œboxieâ€, which is a little longer and less maintenance, says James Bickmore, art director at Neil Moodie Studio. â€œItâ€™s perfect for those who are growing out a pixie but donâ€™t want a bob,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s easy to manage and gets better as it grows out. It has a very â€˜I woke up like thisâ€™ vibe â€” with a bit of an edge.â€ Take inspiration from content creator Rubi on Instagram. The Low Cut View this post on Instagram A post shared by barbie â„¢ (@loc._queen) Lorraine Dublin, a celebrity hairstylist, hair expert and educator, predicts that the â€œlowâ€ cut â€” as seen on Rihanna recently â€” is going to be a bold and beautiful hair statement in 2025. â€œThis style showcases how to elevate your natural curls while keeping things low maintenance,â€ says Dublin. â€œTo achieve this look, start by cutting your 4A curls to remove dead ends and any chemical treatments. Rihanna opts for a shorter length, but this style can also be customized with slightly longer layers for a softer look.â€ Keen to go even shorter? Look to model @loc._queen on Instagram. As for colou, Dublin says that golden tones add warmth and dimension, complementing the texture beautifully. â€œTo style, Iâ€™d recommend starting with a hydrating shampoo and conditioner, followed by a deep-conditioning mask,â€ says Dublin. â€œFenty Comeback Kid Leave-In Conditioner, $36, and Homecurl Curl Defining Cream, $28, are perfect for enhancing and shaping curls,â€ she adds. â€œUse your fingers or a wide-tooth comb to define the curls further, creating a polished yet effortless finish.â€ Bangs-Meets-Layers View this post on Instagram A post shared by G R A C E A M E L I A (@graceamelia___) If it isnâ€™t broken, donâ€™t fix it, suggests Zoe Adams, international artist at Taylor Taylor London. â€œ[Bangs] paired with layers is making a strong comeback for 2025, offering a soft and romantic aesthetic,â€ she says. â€œThe layered structure creates movement, while the bangs frame the face, adding definition and depth.â€ Even better, this style is ideal for most hair lengths, says Adams, but it works especially well for those with thicker hair looking to add lightness and shape. Anything goes, too. â€œCurtain bangs, wispy [bangs] or bold, blunt bangs can all complement layered cuts beautifully,â€ says Adams. This heavily layered cut by Grace Amelia hits the nail on the head. The Mixie â€™25 View this post on Instagram A post shared by Hair by Andy Judd (@andy_doesyourhair) Cut by Andy Judd, this mullet-meets-pixie on Addie Jean Carroll is the cut of 2025. â€œThe mixie is full of texture,â€ says Rice. â€œItâ€™s essentially an outgrown pixie with soft edges around the hairline, but length at the back can be kept longer to create a wolf cut variation.â€ According to Rice, the less styling, the better. â€œWear it natural for a â€˜bedheadâ€™ look,â€ she says. â€œConsider heavily texturized [bangs]; the length can be adjusted to your taste.â€ The Italian Bob 2.0 View this post on Instagram A post shared by Athisha Khan (@athishakhan) With both Bickmore and Adams singing its praises, the Italian bob is in no danger of becoming outdated, but thanks to the abundance of nifty hot brushes out there, weâ€™re going to play around with the size. Take a cue from this cut on Athisha Khan. Try the ghd Rise Professional Hot Brush, $167. Characterized by soft, subtle layers that sit just above the shoulders, Bickmore says the Italian bob offers the perfect balance of volume and movement. â€œItâ€™s effortlessly chic, low maintenance and works beautifully with natural textures, making it an ideal choice for those looking to combine style with ease,â€ he says. If your hair is on the fine side, Adams suggests asking your stylist for blunt ends to maximize the volume. â€œWhether styled sleek or with a soft wave, the Italian bob adds a touch of European elegance to any look,â€ she says. Triple XL Hair View this post on Instagram A post shared by Alyssa / curly hair friend â€ (@alyssarxs) XL = extra long Ã  la Charli xcx. â€œWeâ€™ve been seeing so much long long long hair (hence triple XL), and itâ€™s mostly worn with natural texture,â€ says Rice, like this cut on digital creator Alyssa. â€œAchieving this look wonâ€™t happen overnight but as weâ€™ve seen so many times on the catwalk or in editorials, you can opt for a little help from clip-in extensions.â€ And if your hair is naturally this long? Maintain it well, says Rice: â€œGet your hair cut regularly â€” every six to eight weeks â€” and invest in conditioning treatments.â€ Try Davines Nou Nou Hair Mask, $40. â€œIf your hair is [naturally wavy or curly], let it air-dry or diffuse and use a hair wand for extra waves if needed,â€ adds Rice. Try ghd Creative Curl Wand, $209. The Short Pixie Wig View this post on Instagram A post shared by G R A C E A M E L I A (@graceamelia___) If you donâ€™t want to brave the scissors, Dublin says that a short pixie wig is an excellent way to play with a new style and shade sans permanent change. â€œThis protective style allows you to enjoy a bold, cropped look without cutting or coloring your natural hair,â€ she says, pinpointing Leomie Anderson as inspiration. â€œWigs and extensions are also perfect for people who frequently change their hairstyles or need to protect their hair from damage,â€ she says. â€œIf youâ€™re looking for versatility and protection, this trend is a game-changer.â€ Look to digital creator Thai. Brow Bone Contouring View this post on Instagram A post shared by Q. (@callherrq) Bangs will become mini hairstyles in their own right, suggests hairstylist Tom Smith. â€œIn 2025 weâ€™ll see a variety of fusions of previously popular [bang] styles,â€ he tells R29. â€œBirkin bangs [inspired by the late Jane Birkin], bottleneck bangs [between curtain bangs and full bangs], curtain bangs, micro [bangs] and various other brow- and cheekbone-skimming lengths will be customized to frame the eyes with softly textured and choppy pieces.â€ â€œ[Bangs] like these are great for those who want something low-commitment because theyâ€™re softer and grow out gently, meaning they donâ€™t require regular trimming,â€ adds Smith. He suggests asking your stylist what would work best for your face shape: â€œ[This is important because theyâ€™ll] consider the size of your forehead, whether you want to show off your eyebrows or cheekbones and make sure youâ€™re willing to tweak the style every morning. Youâ€™ll need to reset this area of your hair every day, so while it can be done quickly, it does require some daily maintenance.â€ We love these face-framing bangs on digital creator Q. The Modern Curly Mullet View this post on Instagram A post shared by Tiff McColl ğŸ¸ğŸ§šğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸ğŸ’ ğŸ•ğŸ•â€ğŸ¦º âœ¨FREE PALESTINEğŸ‰ (@tiffmccoll) The mullet is making a major comeback, according to Dublin, and the modern iteration is made for those with curly hair. â€œ[Women with curls] are reimagining this iconic cut with their natural textures,â€ says Dublin. â€œThe look features shorter layers at the top and sides with longer, free-flowing curls at the back,â€ she adds, much like this style by hairstylist Tiff McColl. â€œThe shape enhances volume and movement, and itâ€™s perfect for those who want to push boundaries and pay homage to a style with rich cultural history while staying true to their natural hair pattern,â€ adds Dublin.Â She recommends adding a leave-in conditioner and a curl-enhancing cream to your hairstyling arsenal. Try Cantu Argan Oil Leave-In Conditioning Repair Cream, $6.48, and Living Proof Curl Enhancer, $51.50. Anti Bangs View this post on Instagram A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair) â€œConsidering that weâ€™ve had so much interest in [bang] shapes over the past few years, I predict that 2025 is going to invite in [the opposite] in the form of elongated face-framing â€” no distinguishable layers or shaping around the face, but lengths that sit longer than the chin,â€ says Smith. Ryenne Snow nails it with this cut.Â The key to maintaining [bangs] like these is being kind on your strands. â€œAvoid splitting by turning down the heat on your tools and using a product like Olaplex No.3,â€ says Smith, which reduces breakage. â€œConcentrate it around the weaker hairline areas and be gentle when brushing,â€ he adds. The Luxe Bob View this post on Instagram A post shared by B L O N D E HELSINKIğŸ‡«ğŸ‡® (@blondehelsinki) The classic lob, aka long bob, will get a sleek, luxurious upgrade for 2025, says Sam Burnett, owner and creative director of Hare & Bone salon. â€œThis cut sits just above the shoulders, with seamless layers throughout the mid-lengths and ultra-blunt edges that create a polished, clean finish,â€ says Burnett, like this cut by Blonde Helsinki. â€œItâ€™s modern, low-maintenance and perfect for anyone who wants versatility because it can be air-dried for an effortless vibe or styled for an ultra-refined look,â€ says Burnett.Â  The Midi Flick View this post on Instagram A post shared by Francesca Inverarity (@frankie_inv) Smith cites Florence Pugh and Kendall Jenner as celebrity inspiration but this chunky, flicky, mid-length cut on Sana, created by Francesca Inverarity of The Hair Bros, is by far our favorite look. â€œThanks to the virality of 2024â€™s â€˜bell bottomâ€™ bob [a kicked-out bob haircut], weâ€™re going to see flicky and textured mid-length shapes lead the way for [hair] trends in 2025,â€ says Smith.Â He suggests asking your stylist for a textured and layered shape that sits around your collarbone. â€œItâ€™s best styled with soft, messy waves or natural curls if you have them,â€ says Smith. â€œUse a texture spray to modernize and add volume to the result.â€ Try Living Proof Full Dry Volume and Texture Spray, $49. The Layered Curtain Cut View this post on Instagram A post shared by Nataliia Bumford (@nata.boo.hair) â€œThis medium-length cut combines the softness of â€˜70s-inspired layers with a modern edge,â€ says Burnett. title: A Dermatologist Told Me To Make These Skincare Resolutions In 2025
description: Itâ€™s natural to want a fresh start when January rolls around. Some years I say Iâ€™ll exercise more, other years I vow to spend less time on my phone. But without fail my perpetual New Yearâ€™s resolution is to show my skin a little more TLC. While we may stumble over â€” or completely give up on â€” some New Yearâ€™s resolutions, your skincare routine shouldnâ€™t feel like an insurmountable hurdle in 2025. Tiny tweaks can often make a world of difference and thereâ€™s no need to spend a small fortune, either. Ahead, we asked three dermatologists for their straightforward skincare resolutions to aim for in 2025. Trust us, these are goals youâ€™ll actually want to stick to. DashDividers_1_500x100 Try retinal over retinol If your current retinol serum isnâ€™t doing it for you, then it might be time to add retinal into the mix, according to Dr. Marisa Garshick, a board-certified dermatologist at MDCS Dermatology. Retinal or retinaldehyde â€” a skincare ingredient derived from vitamin A â€” is considered more potent than retinol and less irritating than a prescription retinoid (e.g. tretinoin), Dr. Garshick explains. Hereâ€™s how it works: For vitamin A derivatives to have an impact on the skin, they need to be converted to retinoic acid. â€œRetinaldehyde is considered more potent than retinol because it requires fewer steps to be converted to retinoic acid,â€ Dr. Garshick says. In other words, it works much faster. â€œ[Retinal] is a great option for someone who has been able to tolerate retinol but isnâ€™t seeing their desired results,â€ Dr. Garshick continues. If you have dry or sensitive skin which doesnâ€™t do well with strong prescription retinoids, then retinal may also be your answer â€” and you can get it over the counter. Medik8â€™s Crystal Retinal, $54, is available in various strengths for retinal beginners and established retinal users alike. Also try Maelove Moonlight Retinal Serum, $39.95, with moisturizing squalane and ceramides, and R29-favorite Glow Recipe BlackBerry Retinol Blemish Serum, $48. If you want to spend less, try The Ordinary Retinal 0.2% Emulsion, $14.90. Skincare is much more than just your faceÂ  The experts are in agreement: All skincare routines should extend beyond your face. The neck, upper chest and hands are often forgotten about in skincare regimes, explains Dr. Mary Sommerlad, but these areas require just as much attention as your face does. She adds that the skin on the dÃ©colletage can be pretty vulnerable to the effects of excess sun and other elements like cold weather. This doesnâ€™t mean you need to buy a specific dÃ©colletage cream, though. Bringing your usual moisturizer down to the neck and chest area is just as beneficial. But there are rules. â€œ[The skin here is] incredibly delicate and may not tolerate high-strength acids in the same way as the face may,â€ Dr. Sommerlad says. Put simply, the 7% glycolic acid that works wonders on your blackheads could irritate the skin further down. Instead, Dr. Garshick recommends gentle yet effective creams with strengthening peptides, hydrating hyaluronic acid and, of course, sunscreen in the daytime. Her favorite multitasking face products that can also be used on the neck and chest include Kiehlâ€™s Super Multi-Corrective Face and Neck Cream, $76, and Peter Thomas Roth Ultimate Solution 5 Multitasking Moisturizer, $65. Also try Naturium Multi-Peptide Moisturizer, $20, if youâ€™d rather spend less. Look for moisturizers with these special ingredientsÂ  From hydrating niacinamide to moisturizing ceramides, 2024 saw a host of buzzy skincare ingredients. In the new year, growth factors (also known as GF) and peptides are two ingredients which are really going to be worth the hype, hints Dr. Garshick. Growth factors are types of proteins which increase skin hydration and stimulate skin cell generation. They are also notable in boosting and supporting collagen production, the key to supple skin, says Dr. Garshick.Â Then there are peptides. These, too, are proteins which strengthen the skinâ€™s barrier â€” the outermost layer of skin that keeps good stuff in (like moisture) and bad stuff out (like bacteria). Theyâ€™re excellent for smoothing skin thatâ€™s on the dry side. If youâ€™re keen to give growth factors a go, Dr. Garshick recommends trying The Inkey List 15% Vitamin C + EGF Serum, $16. If peptides sound right for you, try Drunk Elephant Protini Polypeptide Cream, $69. Understand how LED masks actually workÂ  LED face masks are being hailed as the simple (though pricy) solution to tighter, smoother skin. In 2025, itâ€™s important to understand how LED masks work if you want to reap the benefits. LED masks combine red, infrared and blue light at different wavelengths to rejuvenate skin. Red light, for example, has been shown to improve acne by reducing inflammation, neutralizing acne-causing bacteria and targeting overactive oil glands. It also activates the skin cells that produce collagen and elastin, promoting skin strength and elasticity.Â  Though LED masks are arguably the must-have tools of the moment, they are not a quick fix. Dr. Sommerlad explains, â€œOnly invest in an LED light if you are prepared to be extremely consistent with use,â€ noting that some manufacturers recommend daily use (or at least multiple times per week) for several months. It pays to follow the instructions of your chosen tool. A well-made LED mask will feature various settings to target different skin concerns. If youâ€™re ready to commit, try the Solawave Light Therapy Face Mask, $349, or the CurrentBody LED Light Therapy Face Mask, $469. Suncreen all year round If youâ€™ve given up sunscreen this winter, youâ€™re probably not the only one. But there are benefits to wearing SPF all year round, not least because 80% of UV rays can penetrate cloud cover, while UVA â€” responsible for premature aging and skin cancer â€” can also make its way through glass windows. NHS dermatology registrar Dr. Sonia Sharma suggests itâ€™s a good idea to get into the routine of wearing sunscreen on a daily basis, even if it is cold and gloomy â€” and regardless of your skin tone. Dr. Sommerlad recommends choosing a lightweight, hydrating sunscreen with an SPF of 30 to 50, plus UVA protection. Try Neutrogena Ultra Sheer Dry-Touch Sunscreen Lotion, SPF70, $9.88, which absorbs quickly and doesnâ€™t leave behind a residue, or Garnier Pure Active BHA+Niacinamide Daily UV SPF50+, $26, which is equally easy to use. If hyperpigmentation is a skin gripe of yours, Dr. Sommerlad suggests trying a tinted sunscreen which also blocks visible light. Try AvÃ¨ne Mineral Multi-Defense Tinted SPF, $36, or La Roche-Posay Anthelios Mineral Tinted Sunscreen, $38.99. Consider mole mapping Besides being diligent with sunscreen, people with a family history of skin cancer, or those with a history of tanning bed use, might also want to consider mole mapping or mole scanning services. Available in various towns and cities across the UK, such services use imaging technology to assess each and every mole on your body, ruling out suspicious and potentially cancerous lesions, as well as tracking any changes to your moles over time. â€œThis is especially useful if you have a lot of moles,â€ says Dr. Sharma, adding, â€œIf you are concerned about new or changing moles, it is important to seek medical attention to have these reviewed.â€ Mole mapping is available in various clinics across the US. Donâ€™t overdo it While TikTokâ€™s 10+ step skincare routines are captivating, skinimalism is the ultimate skincare mantra for 2025. Dr. Sharma advises against simultaneously using multiple skincare products with many different active ingredients, such as glycolic acid and retinoids. â€œUsing lots of different skincare products can actually weaken the skin barrier [the outermost layer of skin] and cause more problems,â€ she explains, manifesting in dryness, sensitivity and inflammation. Dr Sommerlad advises prioritizing a healthy skin barrier. Her advice is to use gentle cleansers and moisturizers that contain humectants â€” ingredients that attract moisture into the skin. Hyaluronic acid and glycerin are some of the best known examples of such ingredients.Â Besides these, ceramides and peptides can also help to nourish, restore and maintain a healthy skin barrier, allowing you to get closer to your skincare goals. â€œWorking consistently with effective yet gentle ingredients leads to longer term, sustainable results,â€ Dr. Sommerlad says. Cautious exfoliation Lastly, Dr. Garshick says that over-exfoliation needs to be left behind in 2024. â€œWhile it may be tempting [seeing as it leaves] the skin [feeling] softer and smoother, exfoliating too often â€” or too aggressively [using physical scrubs] â€” can actually create micro-tears in the skin which can lead to skin irritation and redness,â€ she explains. If alpha hydroxy acids (AHAs) like glycolic or lactic acid are a little too harsh for your skin type, look out for products containing poly hydroxy acids (PHAs) instead. These are made up of larger molecules and therefore donâ€™t penetrate the skin as deeply but still have the power to smooth skin and unclog pores over time. Like what you see? title: I Tried the Upside-Down Hair-Washing Trick That's All Over TikTok
description: I've washed my hair countless times, but I've never considered changing the way that I did it. I've always rinsed, shampooed, rinsed, conditioned, and rinsed one last time. Why fix what's not broken, right? But TikTok has other ideas. One night, I stumbled across a video on upside-down hair washing, in which the creator shared her hair-care routine that included shampooing and conditioning her head in the shower upside down. When I told the rest of the beauty team about this strange hair-washing technique, all but one person - who regularly follows this hack, as well as the reverse hair-washing technique herself - were just as surprised as I was. The reasoning for doing this, so I'm told, is to help add volume and body to any hair type - especially if it's fine. And as someone who fits that description, I was game to try it. The next time I showered, instead of using my shampoo and conditioner the way I've done it for the past two-plus decades, I flipped my head upside down. First, I'll say this: in order to pull off upside-down hair washing, you absolutely need a detachable shower head with a hose. But even with that, it's no easy task. The entire practice felt very strange - water gets everywhere if you're not careful. I used my Balmain Homme Treatment Bodyfying Shampoo ($72) and Balmain Homme Treatment Bodyfying Conditioner ($87) for the process, which already boast volumizing ingredients. With my head upside down and the shower nozzle dangling quite frantically, I lathered the roots of my hair, concentrating the shampoo on my scalp and not really worrying about washing my ends. Once that step was done, still with my head upside down (water in my ears, and soap in my eyes. . .), I rinsed the shampoo out. Using my conditioner next, I focused on the ends of my hair this time, avoiding my roots - something I do when I wash my hair right side up, too, to keep from weighing my hair down. After giving my head one final rinse, I was finished with the entire upside-down hair-washing process. It definitely took me longer than usual to do, but my hair surprisingly already felt softer to the touch, which gave me hope. Out of the shower, I put my hair up in a towel to dry a little bit before putting in a styling cream and blasting it with some heat (also while upside down - are you sensing a theme?). Already, my hair looked fluffier and had more volume, especially at the roots, which usually lay flat against my head. Because at this point I looked a little bit like a poodle that just got blow-dried, I decided to curl my hair with my Mermade Waver to see how that'd look. This is where the magic really happened. My hair retained its volume and had so much more bounce than it usually does. Despite being chaotic to do, upside-down hair washing really did give my fine hair next-level body, and the result was long lasting. This is definitely a trick I'll keep up my sleeve for days when I plan on heat styling in the future. Jessica Harrington (she/her) is the senior editor of PS Beauty, where she oversees coverage around makeup, skin care, hair, tattoos, and more. With more than eight years of industry experience, she has interviewed countless celebrities, reported on hundreds of beauty trends, and swatched more lipsticks than she can count. Prior to PS, Jessica worked for publications such as Makeup.com, Skincare.com, and The Zoe Report.
